descript.abstract: The EC tower is operated as part of the Next Generation Ecosystem Experiment-Arctic (NGEE) at Barrow, Alaska. The tower is collecting flux data from the beginning of the thaw season, early June, and until conditions are completely frozen, early November. The tower is equipped with a Gill R3-50 Sonic Anemometer, LI-7700 (CH4) sensor, a LI-7500A (CO2/H2O) sensor, and radiation sensors (Kipp & Zonen CNR-4 (four component radiometer), two LiCor LI-190 quantum sensors (PAR upwelling and downwelling), and a down-looking Apogee SI-111 infrared radiometer (surface temperature)). The sensors are remotely controlled, and communication with the tower allows us to retrieve information in real time. doi:10.5440/1124200, http://dx.doi.org/10.5440/1124200
descript.purpose: Quantify the integrated climate forcing from ecosystem greenhouse gas, energy, and water fluxes across a range of permafrost conditions and spatial scales and document improvement in model predictive skill of this forcing.

ome.datause: The EC tower measures fluxes originating from the area surrounding it. The prevailing wind direction at the BEO (55% of the time) come from the NE-SE sector. Data is presented in half-hourly averages. For each measured variable, a unique column of data is prepared, with values representing each half-hour. Measurements have gone through a QA/QC process to remove bad data. The data set is not gap-filled. Therefore missing data can be associated either with technical issues or weather conditions in which flux theory does not apply, or other problems. -9999 represent missing data It is highly recommended that only data with QC value of 0 (no issue) will be used.
